messageBody:
--- "David Jackman" <david.jackman@f...> wrote:
> It's the same as testing any other method. Set up the test,
> call the method, then verify the output.

To amplify David's example...

[The "main" method being tested.]

import java.io.*;
public class Main {
public static void main(final String[] args) {
if (args.length > 0) {
System.out.print("echo");
for (int argIdx = 0; argIdx < args.length; ++argIdx) {
System.out.print(" " + args[argIdx]);
}
System.out.println();
}
final BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new
InputStreamReader(System.in));
try {
while (reader.ready()) {
final String inputLine = reader.readLine();
System.out.println("input: " + inputLine);
}
} catch (final IOException ex) {
ex.printStackTrace();
}
}
}

[The JUnit tests.]

import java.io.*;
import junit.framework.TestCase;
public class MainTest extends TestCase {
public void testMain() {
final String[] commandLineParameters = new String[]
{"A", "B", "C"};
final String systemIn =
"one\n" +
"two\n" +
"three";
// Setup input and output.
System.setIn(new ByteArrayInputStream(systemIn.getBytes()));
final ByteArrayOutputStream output = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
System.setOut(new PrintStream(output));
// Call the main method
Main.main(commandLineParameters);
// Verify the output
final String nl = "\r\n";
assertEquals(
"echo A B C" + nl +
"input: one" + nl +
"input: two" + nl +
"input: three" + nl,
output.toString());
}
public void testMainNoData() {
final String[] commandLineParameters = new String[] {};
final String systemIn = "";
// Setup input and output.
System.setIn(new ByteArrayInputStream(systemIn.getBytes()));
final ByteArrayOutputStream output = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
System.setOut(new PrintStream(output));
// Call the main method
Main.main(commandLineParameters);
// Verify the output
assertEquals("", output.toString());
}
}
